PatientMatching.TEXT:
Record date: 2080-05-17
WMH EMERGENCY DEPT VISIT
JOHNSON,PEPPER E. 537-18-74-8 VISIT DATE: 05/17/80 PRESENTING COMPLAINT: This patient is a 50-year-old male that presents to Wausau Memorial Hospital Department of Emergency Medicine with complaints of noticing a small amount of blood on his underwear this a.m. HISTORY OF PRESENTING COMPLAINT: He also noted a similar effect at 1400 hours today while at work. He denies any fevers, chills, he denies any burning or urgency on urination, he denies having a new sexual partner. He denies of having a past medical history of this problem. PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: Diabetes since 2068. MEDICATIONS: Insulin for diabetes. ALLERGIES: None known. PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: HEENT: Normocephalic, atraumatic. Pupils: Equal, round, reactive. Fundi positive for AV nicking. Neck was supple, no JVD. Chest was clear to auscultation and percussion, no rales, wheeze, or rhonchi. Heart: Normal S1, S2, no S3, S4, no murmur. Abdomen was soft, benign, nontender without masses, guarding, rebound, or organomegaly. Extremities: Grossly within normal limits. The patient was noted to have negative flank pain. Examination of the penis noted a circumcised male, there were no abrasions, erosions, or penile discharge noted. There was no tenderness noted. There was no blood noted at the meatus. LABORATORY EVALUATION: The patient had a UA done in the ED. The UA was noted to be negative. However, it was positive for 2+ glucose but it was negative for blood. The patient also had a set of electrolytes done to monitor kidney function and he was found to have a glucose of 176, BUN 11, creatinine of 0.9, sodium of 140, potassium 4.2, chloride 102, and a CO2 of 27. FINAL DIAGNOSIS: Gross hematuria, resolved. DISPOSITION (including condition upon discharge): The plan is to discharge the patient home, to place him on Bactrim 1 tab p.o. b.i.d. and have him followed up by his PMD. Condition on discharge is satisfactory. ___________________________________ MQ775/2509 H. U. HEBERT, M.D. UH02 D:05/17/80 T:05/19/80 Dictated by: H. U. HEBERT, M.D. UH02 ******** Not reviewed by Attending Physician ********
**************************************************************************************************** Record date: 2081-02-17
WMH EMERGENCY DEPT VISIT
JOHNSON,PEPPER E. 537-18-74-8 VISIT DATE: 02/17/81 Patient seen and evaluated with Dr. Collins. I agree with Dr. Collins's note. HISTORY OF PRESENTING COMPLAINT: The patient is a 51 year old male with a history of a fever over the last two days. He has had some URI symptoms and increasing glucose requiring increased insulin. Fever of 102 today. He has had a cough productive of some yellowish sputum but no real shortness of breath, no dysuria, no urgency, no frequency, no diarrhea, no melena, no bright red blood per rectum, no nausea or vomiting. PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: Diabetes. MEDICATIONS: Per the resident's note. ALLERGIES: Per the resident's note. SOCIAL HISTORY AND FAMILY HISTORY: Per the resident's note. PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: Well nourished, well developed male, slightly tachycardic initially, in no acute distress. Skin: Warm and dry without rash. HEENT: Normocephalic, atraumatic, oropharynx clear. Neck: Supple, full range of motion. Lungs: Clear. Heart: Regular rate and rhythm. Abdomen: Soft. LABORATORY EVALUATION: Chest x-ray clear. FINAL DIAGNOSIS: Bronchitis, viral syndrome. DISPOSITION (including condition upon discharge): Plan is Albuterol and Erythromycin, followup with PMD. Condition on discharge is stable. ___________________________________ TP009/2221 OWEN URE, M.D. OU98 D:02/17/81 T:02/18/81 Dictated by: OWEN URE, M.D. OU98 ******** Not reviewed by Attending Physician ********
**************************************************************************************************** Record date: 2081-12-23
WMH EMERGENCY DEPT VISIT
JOHNSON,PEPPER E. 537-18-74-8 VISIT DATE: 12/23/81 The patient was seen by me and examined. Briefly, the history is as follows. HISTORY OF PRESENTING COMPLAINT: The patient is a 52 year-old black male with multiple cardiac risk factors including insulin dependent diabetes, hypertension, and hypercholesterolemia, who now presents for evaluation of chest pain. The patient states he developed substernal chest pressure this a.m. at approximately 9 o'clock, associated with nausea, shortness of breath, diaphoresis, and generalized weakness. He states the discomfort was a substernal tightness without radiation. At the present time he states the pain is approximately 4/10 in intensity. Of note, the patient had a stress test done on December 6, 2081, standard Bruce, for which he exercised 7 minutes, 30 seconds and stopped secondary to fatigue. He went 74 percent of predicted and developed no symptoms. The test revealed no evidence of ischemia. PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: As noted above. MEDICATIONS: Lopressor, amoxicillin, aspirin, insulin, nitroglycerin p.r.n., Claritin, lisinopril, and Zocor. ALLERGIES: No known drug allergies. SOCIAL HISTORY AND FAMILY HISTORY: The patient denies smoking. PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: GENERAL: Well-developed, well-nourished, pleasant male in no acute distress. VITAL SIGNS: Temperature 97, blood pressure 108/62, pulse 80, respiratory rate 18, O2 saturation 97 percent on room air. HEENT: Mucous membranes were moist without lesions. NECK: Supple without jugular venous distension. LUNGS: Clear to auscultation. HEART: Regular rate and rhythm without murmurs, rubs or gallops. ABDOMEN: Soft, non-tender and non-distended. EXTREMITIES: No clubbing, cyanosis or edema. No calf tenderness. Negative Homan's sign. NEUROLOGIC: Awake, alert and oriented times three, non-focal. LABORATORY EVALUATION: CBC: White count 8.9, hematocrit 40.8, platelets 323,000. CPK was 1213, MB 10.5. SMA-7 was within normal limits. Cardiac troponin was 0.04. EKG showed normal sinus rhythm with nonspecific T-wave changes. There was a flipped T-wave in leads 1 and aVL, which is unchanged compared with prior tracing dated December 6, 2081. THERAPY RENDERED/COURSE IN ED: The patient was treated in the emergency department with O2, two liters via nasal cannula, nitroglycerin 1/150 sublingual times three, Lopressor 25 mg p.o., and aspirin 325 mg p.o. The patient became pain-free and remained hemodynamically stable. FINAL DIAGNOSIS: Chest pain, rule out myocardial infarction. DISPOSITION (including condition upon discharge): The patient will be admitted to the medical service for further evaluation and management, including usual rule out myocardial infarction protocol. He was admitted in stable condition. ___________________________________ BW018/5369 URIEL ERVIN, M.D. UE24 D:12/23/81 T:12/24/81 Dictated by: URIEL ERVIN, M.D. UE24 ******** Not reviewed by Attending Physician ********
**************************************************************************************************** Record date: 2085-06-13
EDVISIT^53718748^Johnson, Pepper^06/13/85^UMANA, BRUCE
The patient was seen by me along with Dr. Abbott on 06/13/2085.
The history is documented by Dr. Abbott, was reviewed by me with
the patient, found to be accurate and complete. The physical
exam was confirmed by my examination. Evaluation and management
was also concurred with.
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: In brief, this is a 56-year-old male
who enters with a history of after sitting playing a piano,
developed shortness of breath, had decreased ability to breathe.
Says he had some diaphoresis this morning, dyspnea on exertion
which he has noted that he has been having repeated exertional
dyspnea over the past several days, worsening today when he had
diaphoresis accompanying with no chest pain but felt confused and
did not know where he is supposed to be going in the building until
he was overhead paged to report to specific room, when he looked
up 25 minutes had gone by and he was unaware of what had happened
during that time. He has had some mild upper respiratory tract
infection about a week ago. No nausea, no vomiting, no
dizziness, no abdominal pain, and the patient states that he is
feeling much better while he was being given some oxygen but just
feels like he has no energy. The patient had a cardiac
catheterization in December of 2081 and had a luminal
irregularities and 30% stenosis and echocardiogram revealed 55%
ejection fraction.
PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: The patient has history of coronary
disease, MI, and hypercholesterolemia.
SOCIAL HISTORY: Smoked in the past for 30 years. He is a
Senior Manager of Broadcasting by occupation. Lives with his family.
Review of systems, allergies, and medications are as documented
in the chart. Please see Dr. Abbott' notes for details.
PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: Awake, alert, well-developed,
well-nourished male in mild distress. Temperature 96.6, pulse
100, respirations 20, blood pressure 164/86. Lungs clear.
Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm. Abdomen is flat,
nondistended, bowel sounds normoactive, nontender, no pedal
edema.
LABORATORY DATA: White count 7.9, electrolytes are normal,
hematocrit 36. CK was elevated at 657, troponin was negative.
The patient's D-dimer was 211 and an EKG showed T-wave inversions
in aVL, V5 and V6 which ________ from previous chest x-ray was
negative.
DIAGNOSIS: Acute coronary syndrome, rule out myocardial
infarction.
As such was admitted to Medicine on 06/13/2085.
______________________________
UMANA, BRUCE M.D.
